comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This may be Willoughby Falls. There are two views of Willoughby Falls in the Tyrrell Collection on Flickr 1. www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2415290398/ 2. www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2415288660/ And there is a good view of the falls @ Macleay Museum by Robert Hunt (1860) here: www.usyd.edu.au/museums/collections/macleay/hist_photos/v... However I'm not sure,so I'm not putting a tag with that name on this photograph yet.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I believe it is located in Primrose Park, and I'm going there next week to see what sort of comparison shot I can get. Searching for "Willoughby Falls" in Picture Australia is also helpful: www.pictureaustralia.org/apps/pictureaustralia?term1=will... As is searching for "Primrose Park" www.pictureaustralia.org/apps/pictureaustralia?action=PAS... this last result for Primrose Park reveals no waterfalls, so I'm not confident they exist any more. Although this page from North Sydney council suggests the falls still exist in the park: www.northsydney.nsw.gov.au/www/html/2247-primrose-park.asp

comment.author: 45104424@N00
comment._content: lifeasdaddy If you go, there are two access points. There is a track behind the tennis courts, or, from the top, there is some stonework on Grafton St, which is the top of that track. I live a couple of hundred metres away, but am a tad lame at the moment.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: iansand - Thanks. I visited yesterday and today with inconclusive results. I'm not lame at the moment, but was a bit too scared to get the required shot. Scared of falling and a trip to the hospital that is. I looked down over the stone fencing near Grafton Street, but could not see the path leading up to there. Now you've told me there's a path behind the tennis courts, I'll make another visit and see what I can see. See my blog here for the story up to the moment: lifeasdaddy.typepad.com/lifeasdaddy/2009/02/sydney-then-a...

comment.author: 45104424@N00
comment._content: The path down from Grafton St starts near the Neutral Bay end of the fortifications. I agree - the falls are not easy to get to. I have looked a couple of times and decided discretion was the wisest course. -- Seen on my Flickr home page. (?)

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Peter Ansell has taken a recent photograph of Willoughby Falls, and now I think that the photograph above is not of Willoughby Falls. Refer to the comments section on my blog post about this matter here: lifeasdaddy.typepad.com/lifeasdaddy/2009/02/sydney-then-a... and Peter Ansell's recent photograph of Willoughby Falls here: www.panoramio.com/photo/15704933 I guess we'll have to check Fairy Falls, North Lawson, as opsbooks suggests.

comment._content: It's amazing.. this camera is almost as good as mine nowadays. >_>

comment.author: 78702393@N06
comment._content:
Why the Puzzle?

It's the Lower Loddon Falls just off the Appin Road NSW - about a kilometre south in from the Loddon River bridge. It's water catchment area today and entry is prohibited - and hefty fines imposed on those caught tresspassing.

I've been their twice in the company of (and with the permission of) the Water Board's rangers. I even wrote and article about it long ago: Loddon Falls [newspaper article]
Author: Davis, Joseph, 1956-
Source: Illawarra Mercury [microform], Monday, 01 August 1988, p. 11
Summary: Loddon Falls was once an area of immense natural beauty and an acclaimed picnic spot, and this article documents the history of the Falls area, and what it has become today.
Language: English
Article Length: 1/2 page to page
Article Type: Feature
Article Graphics: Illustrations
Subject: Loddon Falls (N.S.W.)
Sherbrooke (N.S.W.) -- History
Lawrence, D. H. (David Herbert), 1885-1930 -- Homes and haunts -- New South Wales -- Thirroul

even the National Library identifies the image accurately on line: 
# nla.pic-vn5530767
# PIC/14672/3 LOC Album 70
# Kerry, Charles H. (Charles Henry), 1858-1928.
# Lower Fall, Loddon River, New South Wales, ca. 1880s, 2 [picture]
# 188- 1 photograph : albumen ; 19.5 x 15 cm.
# Part of Album of towns and coastal scenes, Illawarra, New South Wales, ca. 1880s [picture]
